Trur simplest type of obligation is that in which there is but a single creditor and a single debtor. There may, however, possibly be two or more creditors, or two or more debtors, in the same obligation. Sometimes, it is true, this plurality of parties is apparent only, and not real: it is seen, on a closer scrutiny, that there are, in reality, a “ number oi separate obligations, each with its single creditor and its single debtor, and each distinguishable from each ol the rest: the misapprehension arising from the fact that there is something which connects the several obligations with one another. For instance, it A, B, and C jointly promise 5l. to D, or if D promises r5l. to A, B, and C jointly, D can claim only 5l. from each ol the promisors singly, or each of the promiscas can recover only 5l. from him Or again, it a debtor or creditor dies, leaving several joint heirs, they are en- titled or bound, and can sue or be sued, only in the ratio ol their shares in the inheritance. In all these cases there is no single obli- gation with a plurahty ol parties on either the creditor or the debtor side: there is a number of separate and distinct obligations, which, in our minds, are connected together by the unity ol the mode in which they originate.
